newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Rwanda warns Central African Republic on Hutus.
newsitem.headline: Rwanda warns Central African Republic on Hutus.

text.p: Rwanda on Saturday accused the Central African Republic of giving refuge to armed Rwandan Hutus fleeing rebels in Zaire and warned this was dangerous.

A senior aide to Rwandan Vice-President and Defence Minister Major-General Paul Kagame said former Rwandan Hutu army chief of staff Major-General Augustine Bizimungu and his deputy recently fled into the Central African Republic from neighbouring Zaire.
Rwanda's government accuses Bizimungu of helping lead the genocide that claimed the lives of an estimated 800,000 Tutsis and Hutu moderates in Rwanda in 1994.
Rwanda supported the Tutsi-dominated rebellion in Zaire and exiled Hutu former Rwandan troops fought alongside Zaire troops.

"We take strong exception to the Central African Republic which is taking in killers who have fled Zaire. They are taking them in without disarming them, a mistake Zaire made in 1994," said the aide, who declined to be named.
"Rwanda wishes to warn the Central African Republic about the dangers of this...The Central African Republic must remember that it is far smaller than Zaire," he said in a veiled threat.

The aide told Reuters Rwanda had information that Bizimungu's deputy, former chief of combat operations Brigadier-General Gratien Kabiligi, was now in Kenya and hoped that Kenya was not allowing in "armed elements" like the Central African Republic.
"Rwanda reserves the right to take whatever action it deems necessary to bring these killers under control," he said.

Rwanda has repeatedly denied Zairean government accusations it had sent its troops to fight alongside the Tutsi-dominated rebels, who cleared eastern Zaire of Rwandan Hutu rebel bases inside refugee camps at the start of their revolt in October.
